text: hey everyone Thomas Joseph here now does
your chicken piccata turn out like this
dry and overcooked maybe really dark on
one side and insipid and colorless on
the other side well today I'm going to
share with you a foolproof method in
making chicken piccata and you will be
making it every week I promise it takes
so little time and so few ingredients
and it's delicious juicy and tender how
do we get started well I'm using chicken
today and that's what I have two chicken
breasts here these are about 8 to 10
ounce chicken breasts and to start this
process and this is something that you
guys can actually have your butcher do
or in your supermarket they sell chicken
cutlets so you wouldn't necessarily have
to do this at home but what you have to
do if you do have these big chicken
breasts here is you have to have this
horizontally so taking a very sharp thin
knife this is a carving knife you're
going to go halfway down the chicken
breast here and you're going to slice
all the way through you can purchase
this at your supermarket these are
called chicken cutlets but chicken
cutlets are usually a little bit more
expensive because there's more work
that's been put into them and it's
actually really easy to do at home so
why not do it there we go we have two
beautiful cutlets and now to this I'm
going to take a piece of plastic wrap
and I'm going to pound this out into an
even quarter inch thickness this is
really what you need to do when you're
making chicken piccata or if you're
making a chicken melon aise anything any
thin cutlet you want to make sure that
you pound it out evenly so that it cooks
evenly throughout and quickly as well
when you're using a meat mallet to pound
out meat make sure that you use the
smooth side of the mallet not the
textured side this will actually tear
and break up the muscle fibers here and
this is a very tender cut of meat so
there's no need to do that so
get a little bit of your aggression out
here
and that looks pretty good you don't
want to exert too much force because you
don't want to really break up the
chicken cutlet you just want to pound it
into a uniform thickness so I'm going to
repeat the process with my other chicken
cutlet here and while you're doing this
make sure you have a pan and preheated
to medium-high heat you want a wide
enough skillet that you can fit more
than one of these chicken cutlets into
but you want to make sure that it's not
too small because otherwise you're going
to overcrowd the pan and you're not
going to get a nice light color to the
cutlet so
so this looks nice and thin I'm going to
discard the plastic wrap here and now
with my fingers I'm going to begin the
process of dredging the chicken cutlets
and what is dredging will dredging is
usually a powdery flowery substance so
it could be like what I'm using today
all-purpose flour it could be a
different type of flour sometimes rice
flours are used for when you're making
fried calamari or something like that
but it's a simple dressing of flour
that's then going to go into the pan and
create a nice bond or brown bits on the
bottom of the pot which will give us a
really great thickening agent for our
sauce so to this flour mixture
you need to season it because this is
what's going to stick to the outside of
the chicken cutlets here and if you do
not season it you're going to have a
flavorless chicken piccata so be
generous here with your salt and pepper
and I'm using my hand to just mix the
two up now you could use your favorite
seasoning blend here if you wanted to
but for a classic chicken piccata the
flavors are pretty typical lemon capers
salt and pepper and a little bit of
white wine and butter so now what I'm
going to do is put my cutlets right into
the flour mixture here coat them on both
sides shake off any excess flour and
then I'm going to put it right back onto
my work surface while I do the other
this technique of making sakata it can
be done with chicken it can be done with
veal it can be done with pork it does
not need to have the classic flavors
that I'm using today you could do this
saute method here and flavor it in many
different ways with different citrus
fruits and different flavorings so I'm
going to get rid of this wash my hands
up and then we're ready to cook these
colors now it's time to cook the cutlets
medium-high heat here and now I'm going
to add a tablespoon of olive oil into
the bottom of the pan you can see the
oil is dancing around so you know that
is caused and to this I'm going to add
about two tablespoons of unsalted butter
now what this does the butter here it
adds really great flavor and
richness to this dish and the oil
increases the heat point of the butter
so that the butter doesn't burn
it'll Brown nicely but it shouldn't burn
because we have the addition of the oil
so now this is all melted it's bubbling
it's popping I'm going to add in our
chicken cutlet so I'm going to fit my
two cutlets in and again guys this is
one of the important tips here you can't
cook too many cutlets at one time so
this recipe it will yield four beautiful
pieces of chicken piccata but you really
should cook them in batches in two so
this is going to take about two to three
minutes per side the problem that people
have with chicken piccata with dry
chicken piccata or chicken in general is
that people overcook it this method with
a very even thickness of the chicken and
only two minutes per side is going to
yield a wonderfully tender juicy and
delicious cutlet
I promise so it's been about two minutes
and you'll know when to flip the chicken
cutlets when you see the edge of the
chicken cutlets start to turn opaque and
that's when you know to flip it and that
you're not over cooking your chicken
cutlets gently flip them over and then
again it's about two more minutes and
then we'll be ready to make our
delicious pan sauce and ready to eat how
quick is that now it's been about two
minutes and I'm going to remove the
chicken cutlets to the plate to rest
while I make the pan sauce do not
discard or ditch any of the stuff in
this pan except for the fat so I'm going
to drain off the fat but leave all of
those wonderful brown bits because again
guys that's all of the wonderful song
discs called and that's all of the bits
of flour that are nice and brown that
has a lot of flavor and it's also going
to stick enough our sauce nicely so to
this I'm going to add three tablespoons
of a white wine now white wine is very
classic to this recipe
vermouth would also be really nice here
cognac if you wanted to get a little bit
of a different flavor but for a classic
chicken piccata it's white wine so this
liquid this process here in the hot pan
is called
deglazing the pan and all of the added
moisture and the stirring and agitation
is helping to release all of those brown
bits and you can see how nice and thick
it is and now at this point since this
is nice and thick and syrupy I'm going
to add in some more on the flavor here
this is three tablespoons of lemon juice
stir that together and while this
reduces I'm going to add two tablespoons
of capers now these are salt pack papers
that I've Rin but you could certainly
use the briny capers if you have them as
well whatever works whatever you have in
your pantry if you haven't tried capers
you really should they have a really
nice saltiness a really nice flavor that
helps to kind of cut through the acidity
and also the fat because guess what
we're going to add a little bit more
butter now just to enrich this saw one
tablespoon stir this around until it's
nicely melted and emulsified into the
sauce I'm going to turn the heat down a
little bit and last but not least and
I'm going to turn the heat off here our
sauce is nice and thick I'm going to add
one tablespoon of chopped parsley this
just freshens it up and you want to make
sure you turn the heat off because you
don't want to really cook this parsley
so now take this really delicious
flavorful sauce and spoon it right over
your well-cooked juicy cutlets and bring
this right to the table guys you can
even serve this with some lemon wedges
that would be fantastic
crusty bread a nice tender green salad
and there you go you have dinner in like
literally like 20 minutes not even from
start to finish
super simple super fast really flavorful
and that conundrum of the dry chicken
piccata
the dry cutlet it's really solved right
